awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RUI: Transduction of Physiological Stress through Species Interactions: Indirect Effects of Climate Change
awd_abstract_narration:
Temperatures on land and in the ocean are rising as a result of increased greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere.  Much research to date has focused on the direct physiological influence of rising temperatures on animals.  However, an important area that has received less attention is to understand how species interactions will change as a result of warming.  This project seeks to characterize the degree to which physiological stresses experienced by one species that is vulnerable to climate change are transduced to a second species through behavioral interactions, even if that second species is not itself vulnerable to climate change.  The proposed research will uncover the multifaceted nature of climate change on physiological health, an important problem for all wildlife, including endangered and economically important species. Undergraduate and graduate students will be involved in all aspects of this work, receiving important scientific training. In addition, the researchers are teaming with secondary school teachers to develop educational modules on climate change and ocean life, and school classrooms will be invited to field sites to observe and participate in scientific research. 

This research will assess physiological and species interaction responses to climate change in a model system for thermal biology: a pair of sympatric intertidal zone porcelain crab species (genus Petrolisthes) that differ in their direct susceptibility to climate change.  Both species occur together on rocky Pacific shores but one species lives in the warmer mid-intertidal zone and the other in the cooler low-intertidal and subtidal zones.  The mid-intertidal species (the competitive dominant) is more sensitive to rising temperatures than the low-intertidal species (the competitive subordinate) due to the thermal performance of each species and the maximal habitat temperatures they experience.  The central hypothesis of the study is that rising temperatures will likely force the mid-intertidal species into the low-intertidal habitat, increasing competitive interactions and causing increased behavioral stress to the low-intertidal species.   That hypothesis will be tested in three studies of crabs in the natural habitat, a manipulated field experiment, and a laboratory experiment: (1) Thermal conditions and distributions of crabs will be measured in their natural environments to determine the degree to which warm conditions increase species co-occurrence and the potential for competitive interactions.  (2) A manipulative field experiment will be conducted to measure behavioral responses to thermal stress in crabs caged at two intertidal heights.  Temperature variation will be regulated by thickness and composition of artificial stones placed over caged crabs, else conditions will vary naturally.  (3) Experimental intertidal zone simulation tanks will be used to test for behavioral and physiological responses of each crab species to thermal stress.  Heat lamps will be used to regulate temperatures under stones with differing degrees of immersion.  In field (2) and laboratory (3) experiments, crab species will be tested separately and in combination.  Physiological condition in all three studies will be assessed from hemolymph  (blood) samples using existing gene expression thermal stress biomarkers and yolk protein assays of reproductive activity.   Gene expression levels of 44 target transcripts and 6 houskeeping genes will be estimated using the NanoString nCounter platform, a non-amplification based direct measurement of mRNA.  Assays of yolk protein (vitellin) from oocytes and yolk protein precursor (vitellogenin) from hemolymph will be performed using antibody-based assays (ELISA) with available antibodies.

por.por_cntn:
This project, led by Principal Investigator Dr. Jonathon Stillman at San Francisco State University, in collaboration with Dr. Brian Tsukimura at California State University Fresno, addressed a central issue of climate change research: how does warming shift the distribution of species through direct physiological responses and, as a result, cause shifts in species interactions due to changes in density-dependent effects.  Our central hypothesis was that the direct effects of habitat warming on organismal physiology of one set of organisms would influence another set of organisms through changes in behavioral interactions.  That phenomenon is well known in some social vertebrates (e.g., birds, humans) where experienced stress can be transmitted through behavioral interactions to cause physiological stress in individuals that did not experience the original stress.  But, that phenomenon is not well known in the context of climate change-induced shifts in species distributions.  

 

We tested the central hypothesis by thorough field-based and laboratory-based studies of intertidal zone Porcelain crabs that are common under stones along the Pacific coast of the USA.  We defined a study site and deployed temperature data loggers underneath stones (where the crabs are found) to characterize the thermal conditions of the upper and lower parts of the distribution of the crab Petrolisthes cinctipes (Fig. 1).  We surveyed the abundance and demographics of crabs distributed along the intertidal zone gradient and discovered that there is a shift in the abundance and size distribution of crabs that is reflected in the size dependence of temperature tolerance and the temperature at which crabs of different sizes are likely to move (Fig. 2).  Neuronal assays suggest that sensory thermoreceptors on the crab?s legs are used to sense temperatures (Emily Lam, MS Thesis, Fig. 2).  We used the physiological data to construct models that describe the distribution, abundance, and demographics of crabs, and used those models to predict that the impacts of climate change will be to cause shifts downward, especially for small crabs, and reduce population size, especially for large crabs (Alma Ceja, MS Thesis; Fig. 3). Those shifts are likely to have ecological impacts as small crabs have higher survivorship high on the shore (where they can escape their predators for more of the time), and large crabs have higher fecundity and competitive dominance.   Density and size-distributions of crabs were collected along with the expression of temperature-responsive genes of field-acclimatized crabs, which showed relatively constant patterns of distribution, abundance, and physiological state over time (Fig. 4).  

 

In aquarium experiments, we examined the effects of density and species assemblages (single species or mixed species) on crab movement, aggressive interactions that result in injury or death, and the expression of genes related to physiological stress and reproduction (Metadel Abegaz, MS Thesis).  Those studies showed a complex set of patterns, including strong lunar dependence on protein and mRNA levels of egg proteins and stress proteins, species differences in response to density stress, and little concordance between protein and mRNA levels of reproductive proteins (Fig. 5).   Finally, we built a custom computer controlled intertidal zone environmental simulation aquarium system in which we were able to reproduce temperature and tide profiles at our field site to test the influence of tidal and thermal variation on crab movement and aggressive interactions (Fig. 6).  In our initial studies we showed that increasing thermal variation caused crabs to move to the lower platform, even though in doing so there was an increase in the amount of aggressive interactions, as evidenced by the proportion of crabs with injuries (Fig. 6).  Unfortunately, shortly after we began to conduct experiments in the intertidal zone environmental simulation aquaria the building in which they were housed was unexpectedly closed, and our research halted.  

 

This project resulted in a highly integrative data set that spans field observations to laboratory experiments, from ecological to organismal to molecular levels of biological organization.  The project trained one postdoctoral scholar, Alex Gunderson, who is now an Assistant Professor at Tulane University, four Masters students, all of whom were female (one is now gender ambiguous), two of whom are underrepresented minorities, three of whom have completed their MS degree (one still needs to complete and file their thesis), and two of whom are now in PhD programs.  The project also trained several undergraduate students, including one who is an underrepresented minority now in a PhD program.  Finally, as a part of this project we organized and conducted a teacher training workshop for Bay Area middle school science teachers interested in incorporating an in-class simulation of field-based sampling and working with those data.  Though the initial workshop was a success we were unable to get the support we needed from our outreach coordinator to expand this part of the project.
